BBDecMak3: ^I had to come back to my journal a few times to make sure that I wasn’t missing any details. This is where I really started to feel like I was making progress.

BowenDecMak1: ^Once I screened out the solutions that definitely wouldn’t work, I wrote the leftover options on a sheet of paper.
BowenDecMak2: ^This left me with a pretty long list, and I had to fight my habit of picking the fastest way forward instead of the best way.
BowenDecMak3: ^I used the decider grid to keep me on track and when I couldn’t make up my mind, I got a friend to bounce around some ideas with me.

JenDecMak1: ^The first strategy was the hardest for me. It was hard to let go of the solutions I liked best.
JenDecMak2: ^But once I considered the potential consequences for each option, it was clear which ones wouldn’t really work out.
JenDecMak3: ^Honestly, it felt like homework, but it feels good to know I’m asking the right questions before eliminating any of my ideas.
JenDecMak4: ^After I narrowed my list down and completed the decider grid, I realized I had a lot more positive options than I thought!
